quoteFirst: "14th. Last night, above 12 P.M., commenced raining; 3 A.M., rained steadily; 7 A.M., same weather;
quoteLast: , a line of low storm-cloud, or scud, showing very sharp and white on the dark back-ground all along the southern sky. This line continues until noon, about 10° at the highest, showing the northern boundary of the storm to the southward; 8 P.M., same bank visible, although in rapid motion eastward; same time clear overhead, with cirrus fringe pointing north from the bank; much lightning in south (W. fresh); so ends.
title: The Philosophy of the Weather. And a Guide to Its Changes
author: Butler, T. B. (Thomas Belden), 1806-1873

quoteFirst: In the meantime the 2nd and 3rd Guards Brigades had captured the Green line, which was not a line of trenches but a line on the map, 100 yards beyond the Iron Cross――Korteker Cabaret road, and therefore easily recognisable as a landmark. At
quoteLast: the 1st Guards Brigade advanced through the leading Brigades, which were to dig in and consolidate the Green line.
title: The Grenadier Guards in the Great War of 1914-1918, Vol. 2 of 3
author: Ponsonby, Frederick, 1867-1935

quoteFirst: Master and man went downstairs together; the door was shut and double-locked. Phileas called a cab from the bottom of Saville Row, and drove to Charing Cross Station. It was
quoteLast: when they reached the railway. Passe-partout jumped out. His master followed, and paid the cabman.
title: Round the World in Eighty Days
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905; Frith, Henry, 1840- [Translator]

quoteFirst: The _Canopus_, Captain Heathcoat S. Grant, reported at 8.47 A.M. that the first two ships were 8 miles off, and that the smoke reported at
quoteLast: appeared to be the smoke of two ships about 20 miles off.
title: The Battle of the Falkland Islands, Before and After
author: Spencer-Cooper, Henry Edmund Harvey, 1884-1968

quoteLast: , sir. The hall clock was striking the half hour as I carried the coffee into the library. Mrs. Trevor was there, and she told me that Miss Beatrice had gone upstairs to dress, so I left her cup on the table, sir.”
title: The Trevor case
author: Lincoln, Natalie Sumner, 1881-1935; Frederick, Edmund, 1870-1949 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: We halted near the upper spring at
quoteLast: , after the usual accident which now occurred daily about that hour. On this occasion Lieutenant Yusuf's shoe stuck in the stirrup when he was dismounting from an unsteady mule; the animal threw him, and he had a somewhat narrow escape from being dragged to death.
title: The Land of Midian (Revisited) — Volume 2
author: Burton, Richard Francis, Sir, 1821-1890

quoteFirst: Zero hour for the Third Army was fixed at 5.20 a.m. on September 27th; but as the 3rd Division on the left and the 5th Division on the right would advance along higher ground than the 42nd, it was arranged that the 42nd should not move until these divisions had had time to make good the higher ground on its flanks. The Lancashire Fusiliers were therefore timed to leave at 7.52 a.m., and the Manchesters at
title: The 42nd (East Lancashire) Division 1914-1918
author: Gibbon, Frederick P.

quoteLast: --FIRST CALL FOR TROOP I shaved and washed, then cleaned the Gat, And had ten minutes left at that.
title: Rhymes of the Rookies: Sunny Side of Soldier Service
author: Christian, W. E.

quoteLast: , Thursday, July 3.—The clock has been put back another hour to correct our time to Greenwich mean time. Position: Longitude 35 degrees 60 minutes west; latitude 53 degrees north.
title: Aircraft
author: David, Evan John, 1877-1961

quoteFirst: We left camp this morning at
quoteLast: The Camp 43 is situated on the right bank of Stark Creek. We travelled in the first instance slightly to the westward of south with the view of reaching the river.
title: Journal of Landsborough's expedition from Carpentaria, in search of Burke & Wills
author: Landsborough, William, 1825-1886

quoteFirst: A carefully concealed Turkish brigade that had escaped the observations of the British airmen lay behind the ridges near the most northern marsh. But the Turkish surprise did not come off as they expected, for General Houghton's column moved forward so swiftly through the dark around the marsh that, at
quoteLast: , he was ready to send a wireless message to his superior officer announcing that he had reached the left rear of the Turkish lines. Everything now being ready for a general attack, General Townshend proceeded to give battle.
title:
The Story of the Great War, Volume 4
Champagne, Artois, Grodno; Fall of Nish; Caucasus; Mesopotamia; Development of Air Strategy; United States and the War
author: Reynolds, Francis J. (Francis Joseph), 1867-1937 [Editor]; Churchill, Allen L. (Allen Leon), 1873- [Editor]; Miller, Francis Trevelyan, 1877-1959 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Leaving this miserable spot with our starving horses, followed the creek, which had now increased to a small river, to the east-south-east, and after two hours' travelling reached a small patch of grass and camped at
quoteLast: ; the bed of the river is nearly dry, only a few shallow pools remaining in the sandy channel, which is ten to fifty yards wide, with smaller side channels, altogether occupying a breadth of nearly 200 yards, dense clumps of melaleuca-trees growing in the intervening banks of sand; large quantities of unio-shell, some five and six inches in length, are found on the banks of the river near the camps of the blacks; Bowman complains of an attack of scurvy, which causes pains in his legs and swelling of the gums.
title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888

quoteLast: to 12.30 P. M.  Cloudy, changing to light rain; a little snow on ground; wind light, south-east; temperature 38 degrees.  Blue Jay, 1; White-breasted Nuthatch, 1; Chickadee, 6; Golden-crowned Kinglet, 2.  Total, 4 species, 10 individuals.
title: The Bird Study Book
author: Pearson, T. Gilbert (Thomas Gilbert), 1873-1943

quoteLast: the signal station reported another column of smoke in sight to the southward, and at 8:45 A.M. the Kent passed down the harbor and took up a station at the entrance.
title:

quoteLast: and had no more than time to get here myself.”
title: Lalage's Lovers

quoteFirst: Very cold during the night, but beautiful morning. This river runs parallel to the Burdekin for some distance and at only a very short distance between. Started at
quoteLast: over the basalt ridges for the sake of better travelling than we are likely to have in the Burdekin, for some distance at least. South for one mile, then east-south-east through open forest with basalt blocks occasionally, and rather swampy-inclined land for two and three-quarter miles.
title: McKinlay's Journal of Exploration in the Interior of Australia
author: McKinlay, John, 1819-1872

title: Report on the Migration of Birds in the Spring and Autumn of 1882. Fourth Report
author: Harvie-Brown, J. A. (John Alexander), 1844-1916; Barrington, Richard Manliffe, 1849-1915; Cordeaux, John, 1831-1899; More, Alexander Goodman, 1830-1895

quoteLast: . Sergeant Lumbe called at my house at ten minutes past the hour--I made a note of the time--and I went immediately. It is about ten minutes' walk to the moat-house from the village."
title: The Hand in the Dark
author: Rees, Arthur J. (Arthur John), 1872-1942
